<s>Z</s>  Zone occasionally passing into each other; and com
municating with those of the next zone by oblique
peduncles alternately passing towards one side and
the others:-150 diam. (N.B. This figure is somewhat <u>ideal</u>, being
made-up from several preparations; but for every point
which it represents, these preparations give warranty).
5,<s>6</s> Nucleus and first two annular zones, <s>of a larger disk</s> exhibiting the typical
conformation; <u>a</u>, <s>the peripheral</s> the central segment; <u>bb</u>, the circumam-
bient segment, from the entire margin of which are
given-off peduncles of sarcode, which give origin to the
first annular zone:- 84 diam.
6. Nucleus and first two annular zones of another disk,
showing a deficiency in the connections of the first annular zone with
the circumambient segment, <s>to exist only</s> for about a third of the cir-
cumference of the latter, between the points <u>cc</u>:- 84 diam.
7. Portion of <s>the</s> one of the <u>surfaces</u> of an animal of complex
 type (as in Fig. 4);-<u>aa</u>, <u>aa</u>, rows of superficial cells, connected at
their two extremities with the annular bands <u>bb</u>, <u>bb'</u>:-
<s>84</s> 150 diam.
